description: The age of the customer may influence their likelihood of churning, as younger customers may be more likely to switch providers or close their accounts.
Customers with higher monthly usage may be more loyal and less likely to churn, as they find the service valuable and essential to their needs.
Customer feedback and satisfaction scores can be indicative of their loyalty, as dissatisfied customers are more likely to churn.
Customers with longer contract lengths may be less likely to churn, as they have committed to using the service for a specified period.
Customers who have frequent interactions with customer support may be more likely to churn, as it could indicate unresolved issues or dissatisfaction.
The presence of competitive offers from other providers may influence a customer's decision to churn, especially if they perceive better value elsewhere.
Customers who experience billing issues or discrepancies may be more likely to churn, as it can lead to frustration and loss of trust.
Significant lifestyle changes such as relocation or job change may influence a customer's decision to churn, as their needs and priorities shift.
Frequent service outages or disruptions could increase the likelihood of churn, as it affects the reliability of the service.

Customers who actively engage with the company's promotional offers, loyalty programs, and community events may be less likely to churn, as they feel a stronger connection to the brand and its values.
